stem: The patient is exhibiting signs of sepsis. Review the electronic health record and highlight the findings that support this diagnosis.

itemContext.sbar: S: John Smith, a 78-year-old male, was admitted 3 days ago for pneumonia. He is currently being treated with IV Vancomycin and Ceftriaxone. B: Mr. Smith has a history of COPD and hypertension. I've noticed an increased work of breathing and altered mental status during my shift. O: At 07:00, his temperature was 38.9°C, heart rate 122 bpm, respiratory rate 28, blood pressure 88/52 mmHg, and SpO2 90% on 2L NC. The patient is lethargic and confused. Urine output has decreased significantly to 20 mL/hr. There's also a notable wound site on his right forearm, at the IV insertion point, which is erythematous with purulent drainage. A: I suspect sepsis secondary to pneumonia and a possible IV site infection. I'm requesting orders for blood cultures, lactate level, and a fluid bolus. I will notify the provider STAT if his condition continues to deteriorate or if any concerning changes occur.

tabs.title: Labs
tabs.content: WBC: 18,000/mm3 (High), Lactate: 4.5 mmol/L (High), Creatinine: 2.1 mg/dL (High), BUN: 35 mg/dL (High), Platelets: 140,000/mm3 (Low), Procalcitonin: 8 ng/mL (High). Blood cultures pending.

tabs.title: MAR
tabs.content: Vancomycin 1g IV q12h (Last dose: 06:00), Ceftriaxone 2g IV q24h (Last dose: 06:00), Acetaminophen 650mg PO q4h PRN for fever, Normal Saline 500mL bolus (Ordered STAT)

tabs.title: Vitals
tabs.content:
03:00: T 38.2°C, HR 110 bpm, RR 24, BP 96/60 mmHg, SpO2 93% on 2L NC
05:00: T 38.5°C, HR 115 bpm, RR 26, BP 90/55 mmHg, SpO2 91% on 2L NC
07:00: T 38.9°C, HR 122 bpm, RR 28, BP 88/52 mmHg, SpO2 90% on 2L NC

rationale.correct: Elevated WBC count (18,000/mm3) indicates the body is fighting an infection. Elevated Lactate (4.5 mmol/L) suggests tissue hypoperfusion. Elevated Creatinine (2.1 mg/dL) and BUN (35 mg/dL) point to kidney injury, possibly due to decreased perfusion. Low Platelets (140,000/mm3) can be a sign of DIC. Elevated Procalcitonin (8 ng/mL) is a strong indicator of bacterial infection and sepsis. Hypotension (BP 88/52 mmHg) is a key sign of septic shock. Tachycardia (HR 122 bpm) is the body's attempt to compensate for decreased perfusion. Tachypnea (RR 28) is the body's attempt to increase oxygenation. Fever (38.9°C) is a systemic inflammatory response to infection.
rationale.incorrect: While the other values presented in the EHR are important for overall patient assessment, they are not the most direct indicators supporting a diagnosis of sepsis. Focusing on the specific criteria for sepsis, such as the presence of infection along with systemic inflammatory response and organ dysfunction, is crucial. Overlooking key lab values or vital signs can lead to a delay in treatment and worsen the patient's condition.
clinicalPearls: Early recognition of sepsis is critical for improved patient outcomes.
Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that requires immediate intervention.
The Surviving Sepsis Campaign guidelines provide evidence-based recommendations for sepsis management.

questionTrap.trap: Students may focus solely on the temperature elevation and overlook other critical indicators like lactate and blood pressure, leading to an incomplete assessment of the patient's condition.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Encourage students to use a systematic approach, like the SOFA or qSOFA score, to assess for sepsis and to consider the constellation of findings rather than relying on a single data point.

mnemonic.title: S.E.P.S.I.S.
mnemonic.expansion: Slurred speech or confusion, Extreme shivering or muscle pain, Passing no urine (in a day), Severe breathlessness, I feel like I’m going to die, Skin mottled or discolored
